page.description: Contacts the USPS web site and looks up the zip code for the specified address. Returns "" if the zip is not found. Returns the first zip code if multiple are available for the specified address.
page.syntax: ZipCode as C = usps_zipcode_lookup(C addr1 ,C city ,C state [,C addr2 [,C urbanization [,C zip5 ]]])

argument.name: addr1
argument.description: The street portion of an address.

argument.name: city
argument.description: The city portion of an address.

argument.name: state
argument.description: The state portion of an address.

argument.name: addr2
argument.description: Optional. Default = "". A second street address.

argument.name: urbanization
argument.description: Optional. Default = "". Urbanization denotes an area, sector, or development within a geographic area. In addition to being a descriptive word, it precedes the name of the area. The URB descriptor, commonly used in Puerto Rican urban areas, is an important part of the addressing format of Puerto Rico, as it describes the location of a given street.

argument.name: zip5
argument.description: Optional. Default = "". A 5 or 9 digit ZIP code. The function truncates 9 digit codes to 5 digits.

page.discussion: The USPS_ZipCode_Lookup() function contacts the USPS web site and looks up the ZIP code for the specified address. The function returns "" (NULL) if the ZIP code is not found. It returns the first ZIP code if multiple are available for the specified address. Note : Use of this function requires an active Internet connection. ZIP codes are used by the US Postal Service (USPS) for addressing mail in the United States.
page.example:
? usps_zipcode_lookup("70 blanchard road", "burlington", "ma") = "01803-5100"
? usps_zipcode_lookup("91 Middlesex Turnpike", "burlington", "ma") = "01803-4922"
? usps_zipcode_lookup("1600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW", "Washington", "DC") = "20500-0003"
